sentences.sentence: We came upon( 偶然碰到 ) them in the dark, so that they could not see our number.
I made one of our men call them by name, to see if I could bring them to surrender( 投降 ).
So he called out as loud as he could to one of them, “Tom Smith! Tom Smith!”
Tom Smith answered immediately, “Is that Robinson?” for it seemed he knew the voice.
The other answered, “For God’s sake, Tom Smith, throw down your arms, and surrender( 投降 ), or you are all dead men this moment.”
“Who must we surrender( 投降 ) to? Where are they?” said Smith again.

“Here’s our captain and fifty men with him, who have been hunting you these two hours. The mutiny( 叛乱 ) leader is killed, Will Fry is wounded, and I am a prisoner. If you do not surrender( 投降 ) you are all lost.” said Robinson.
The captain himself then called out, “You, Smith, you know my voice. If you lay down your arms( 放下武器 ) immediately and submit( 投降 ), you shall have your lives.”
At this, they all laid down their arms, and begged for their lives.
I sent the man that had spoken with them, and two more men, who together tied them all.
They all appeared very ashamed, and begged hard for their lives.
The captain told them they were not his prisoners, but belonged to the governor of the island.
He went on that the governor was an Englishman, who might hang them all there if he pleased.
I now thought of a way to retake( 重新夺回 ) possession of the ship.
I ordered one of the men to call the captain to me, by saying to the captain, “Captain, the commander calls for you.”
Presently the captain replied, “Tell his Excellency( （对高级官员的尊称）阁下 ) I am just coming.”
This amazed( 使惊奇 ) them, and they all believed that the commander was nearby, with his fifty men.
After the captain came to me, I told him my plan for seizing the ship, which he agreed with, and decided to put it into action the next morning.
But, in order to be sure of success, I told him we must divide the prisoners.
He would send two more of the worst of them, and keep them with the other prisoners.
Friday took them to the cave that served as our prison.
I ordered the others to my cottage.
In the morning I sent the captain to talk to them, test them, and tell me whether he thought they might be trusted to go on board and made a surprise attack( 突袭 ) on the ship.
He told them that if they were sent to England they would all be hanged.
Their only chance was that the governor of the island would pardon them if they would join in an attempt to recover the ship.
Any one may guess how readily such an offer was accepted by men in their situation.
They fell down on their knees to the captain, and promised that they would be faithful to him to the last drop of blood.
“Well,” said the captain, “I must go and tell the governor what you say, and see what I can do to persuade him to agree to it.”
So he brought me an account of the mood( 态度 ) he found them in, and that he truly believed they would be faithful.
The captain now had no difficulty before him, except to supply and send out his two boats.
They arranged their business very well, for they left quickly and came up to the ship about midnight.
As soon as they came close to the ship, he made Robinson call to them, and tell them they had found the men and the boat.
Then the captain and the mate( 大副 ) leapt( 跳 ) onto the deck( 甲板 ) with their guns, and immediately knocked down the second mate( 二副 ) and carpenter( 木匠 ) with the handles of their guns.
They secured all the rest that were upon the main deck( 甲板 ).
The men in the other boat secured the front of the ship, making three men they found there prisoners.

When this was done, and all was safe upon the deck( 甲板 ), the captain ordered the mate( 大副 ) to break into the captain’s cabin( 船舱 ), where the new rebel( 反叛者 ) captain was hiding with some of his men.
When the mate( 大副 ) split( 劈开 ) open the door, the rebel( 反叛者 ) captain and his men fired their guns.
They wounded the mate( 大副 ) with a bullet( 子弹 ), and wounded two more of the men, but killed nobody.
The mate( 大副 ), calling for help, rushed into the cabin( 船舱 ), and shot the new captain through the head with his pistol( 手枪 ).
Then the rest surrendered( 投降 ), and the ship was taken without any more lives lost.
As soon as the ship was thus secured, the captain ordered seven guns to be fired, which was the signal agreed upon to give me notice of his success.
I was very glad to hear it, having waited for it till nearly two o’clock in the morning.
Having thus heard the signal clearly, I lay down, and slept very well, till I was surprised with the noise of a gun.
Presently starting up, I heard a man call me by the name of “Governor! Governor!” and I recognized the captain’s voice.
He pulled me into his arms, “My dear friend, there’s your ship. It is all yours, and so are we, and all that belong to it.”
I cast my eyes( 扫视 ) to the ship, and there it rode, within little more than half a mile of the shore.
At first, for some time, I was not able to answer him one word.
At last I broke out into tears, and in a little while after I recovered my speech, I told him I looked upon him as( 将他视为 )  a man sent by Heaven to deliver( 拯救 ) me.

I did not forget to lift up my heart in thankfulness to Heaven, and what heart could resist( 抵抗得住 ) blessing God, who had in such a miraculous( 神奇的 ) manner provided for me in such a wilderness( 荒岛 ).
After these celebrations were past, we began to discuss what was to be done with the prisoners we had.
It was well worth considering whether we could risk taking them with us, especially two of them, whom the captain said he knew were such criminals that there was no trusting them.
Upon this, I told him that I would try to convince( 说服 ) these two that they would be better off( 境遇更好的 ) left upon the island.
“I should be very glad of that,” said the captain, “with all my heart.”
So I called the men to be brought before me, and I told them I had got a full account of their evil( 邪恶的 ) treatment of the captain.
I let them know that it was on my orders the ship had been seized, and I wanted to know why I should not hang them as criminals.
They had nothing to say, except that they begged for my mercy( 宽恕 ).
But I told them I did not know what mercy( 仁慈 ) I could show them, since I had decided to leave the island and go to England.
As for the captain, he could not carry them to England other than( 除了 ) as prisoners in chains, to be tried( 审判 ) for mutiny( 叛乱 ) and stealing the ship.
Then they would be hanged, so that I could not tell what was best for them.
Their only other choice was to risk their lives on the island.
They seemed very thankful for it, and said they would much rather try to stay there than be carried to England to be hanged.
So that issue was decided.
When they had all declared( 表明 ) their willingness to stay, I then told them I would explain to them my methods of living there, to make things easier for them.
So I gave them the whole history of the place, and of my coming to it, and showed them all that they needed to do.
I told them the story also of the seventeen Spaniards that were to be expected, for whom I left a letter.

question.cn: 为什么Robinson派船长去跟那些俘虏谈话？
question.en: Why did Robinson send the captain to talk to the prisoners?

options.cn: 为了检验他们可不可靠。
options.en: To test whether they are reliable or not.

options.cn: 为了征求他们关于夺取船只的建议。
options.en: To ask them for their advice about seizing the ship.

options.cn: 为了逼他们说出叛变的新船长的下落。
options.en: To force them to tell the whereabouts of the new rebel captain.

analysis: 文中说：“In the morning I sent the captain to talk to them, test them, and tell me whether he thought they might be trusted to go on board and made a surprise attack on the ship.”所以选A。

question.cn: 叛变的新船长躲在哪里？
question.en: Where was the new rebel captain hiding?

analysis: 文中说：“When this was done, and all was safe upon deck, the captain ordered the mate to break into the captain’s cabin, where the new rebel captain was hiding with some of his men.”所以选C。

question.cn: 叛变船长剩下来的手下投降了吗？
question.en: Did the rest of the rebel captain's men surrender?

analysis: 文中说：“Then the rest surrendered, and the ship was taken without any more lives lost.”因此选A。

question.cn: 当Robinson看到可以带他回英国的船，最后他做了什么？
question.en: When Robinson saw the ship that would take him back to England, what did he do at last?

options.en: He ran immediately to the ship.

analysis: 文中说：“I cast my eyes to the ship. . . At last I broke out into tears. . . ”所以选B。

question.cn: 那两个不可信赖的俘虏最后怎么了？
question.en: What happened to the two unreliable prisoners they kept?

options.en: They were left on the island.

analysis: 文中说：“Upon this, I told him that I would try to convince these two that they would be better off left upon the island. They seemed very thankful for it, and said they would much rather try to stay there than be carried to England to be hanged. When they had all declared their willingness to stay. . . ”所以选C。
